Ron

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: David Zincavage 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 2:11 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer


  Ron,

  Here are photos, at least, of a non-mon-sukashi tsuba, papered as Yoshiro.

  http://zincavage.org/Yoshiro1.html

  Cheers,
  David


  Ron Hartmann wrote:
  >
  > Hi Peter -
  >
  > No problem (attached). The seller was a gentleman about it and settled 
  > up with me, as expected. There were multiple photos. Soon after I made 
  > this purchase another alike tsuba was offered out of Japan 
  > (350076519430) which looked very nice, but one that I thought looks 
  > newer (to my surprise, of course). I was not trying to get a bargain, 
  > but hoped to discover a Yoshiro work in a different (than mon-sukashi) 
  > for my study. Oh well, maybe next time. Making SF show???
  >
  > Ron
  >
  > ----- Original Message -----
  > From: Peter A Bleed
  > To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com>
  > Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 1:20 PM
  > Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
  >
  > Ron,
  > Fakes coming out of Japan have emerged as a interesting problem for
  > collectors. I- for one - would like to see the eBay image of your recent
  > acquisition. Would you care to post it?
  > Peter
  >
  > I've always enjoyed Heianjo (never owning an Onin work that I know of) 
  > and Yoshiro
  > mon-sukashi works. Always like brass inlay on good iron!
  >
  > To my surprise, I just received what I thought looked like a nice 
  > early iron with
  > brass inlay tsuba, recently purchased of Ebay, my first Ebay purchase 
  > in ages.
  > After 40-odd years I thought I had a good "eye" for such things; just 
  > bought a
  > repro! Yikes! Hope to reverse the deal but must admit that "pictures are
  > deceiving" at times. Looks like an honest mistake on the seller's 
  > part, but it
  > points up the importance of in-hand study. (I think others spotted 
  > this since my
  > bid was much too low if authentic. Just mentioning this to point out 
  > how good (in
  > pictures only) these repros are today.
  >
  > Enjoyed this topic of lacquer on Heianjo works. I once owned a very 
  > similar (or
  > same one?) tsuba that was pointed out here. I need to sit down and 
  > check some of
  > my other early tsuba for lacquer.
  >
  > Ron
  > STL
  >
  > ----- Original Message -----
  > From: Dr. Philip Vos Fellman
  > To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com>
  > Sent: Monday, July 21, 2008 8:42 AM
  > Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] clear lacquer
  >
  > Hi All:
  >
  > Heianjo are complex. For a start, most Heianjo (real Heianjo and not 
  > Edo period
  > copies) are Momoyama period or earlier. They were mainly made just for 
  > a hundred
  > years or so, basically the 16th century. The earlier pieces are 
  > sometimes called
  > Onin, but even if you include this group, you still only get the 
  > period around
  > 1450-1600. That means that they are old. Many were lacquered. Some 
  > were well
  > preserved some were not. The lacquer is part of the overall gestalt. 
  > If you see a
  > hundred Heianjo tsuba, 25 or so will be lacquered, of which 5 will be 
  > in excellent
  > condition, 10 will be decently preserved, 5 will be in need of varying 
  > degrees of
  > restoration and 5 will be dead.
  >
  > Cheers,
  >
  > Shirogitsune
  >
  > --- On Sun, 7/20/08, bungotakadasword <MuramasaIII@... 
  > <mailto:MuramasaIII%40aol.com>> wrote:
  >

  > gang,
  > last time i mentioned noticing ' clear lacquer " on most Heianjo tsuba,
  > people thought i was smoking some good weeds....... ....
  >
  > Typical response was ........... fire scales
  >
  > http://www.nihontok anjipages. com/tosogu. com/
  >
  > how about that ?
  >
  > milt
